The ratio between a ring area on the half sphere and its projection on the plane (at distance d from the origin) goes from 1 to 0, when we move from the pole to the equator (so that d goes from 0 to R). Let's call it r, where r=1-d/R.

In the r-d plane, r draws the right triangle (0,1) (R,0) (0,0) which has R/2 area in the [0,R] domain.
Let's consider the ratio between a ring area on the upper half sphere, and its projection on the bottom half sphere: we get the expression r=1 in the r-d plane, which yields a rectangle with R area, in the [0,R] domain.

The sum of the areas of the projections is obviously πR² (the circle with radius R), and because this sum maps to the R/2 area in the r-d plane, the value R in r-d plane (that corresponds to the total area of the rings on the half sphere), has to map to the double of the circle area, 2πR². The area of the two halves is therefore 4πR².

So I did some calculations: it turns out that turning a sphere into cylinder is purely an area preserving operation. If I use Grant’s idea of projecting a curved rectangle placed on a sphere on to a cylinder, but visualized it in different way: a sphere can be “deformed” as a cylinder. I don’t if this counts as visual calculus, but when I drew the transformations of different area elements around the median, the top and bottom caps, I had found that if I turn these rectangular elements into just mere squares and construct the projection, the areas visually are the same. Hence forth, I found out that if the cylinder has a height of R and radius of R as well, the total surface area results in 2*pi*r^2 + pi*r^2 + pi*r^2 = 4*pi*r^2. This is really amazing because the fun doesn’t stop here:

Now for volume calculations, when you look into how the wedges are projected during the “deformation” process, you’d find out that the differential pyramids that consume the sphere deform into triangular prisms. The volume of the triangular prism from basic geometry yields 1/2(bh)*R where b and h = base and height of the triangle and R is the height of the prism itself. This can be written as A*R where A is the longitudinal cross section of the prism. The pyramid on the other hand can be written and 1/3*A*R. By geometry, it can show that the “deformation” process yields 1/3*A*R volume addition, which means that the volume ratio of the deformation of the spherical “differential wedge”/Cylindrical “differential wedge” is 4/3, which hence proves that the volume of the sphere to the projected cylinder therefore is 4/3, which proves the volume formula.

A bit more than a year ago I first saw this video. Having retired from math olympiads for less than two years at that point, I took it as a personal challenge to solve this problem without looking at the solution.

After about 40 minutes of struggle, I "found" the solution, and after watching the video I was even more proud of myself since my solution was quite different from the one presented in the video. Alas, recently I stumbled upon this video again and while thinking about my solution I found a serious flaw in it. I started working on it again, and found a fix, albeit much less elegant than what I originally thought.


Since my approach is quite a bit different from the one presented by Grant I decided to write my thought process as I remember it in hopes that whoever reads this will learn something new, mostly about mathematics but also maybe a bit about arrogance and humility. (also spoiler alert: there will be a surprising connection to a different video by 3b1b!)



So, my first idea was quite similar to what was done in the video, I tried to reduce randomness by fixing one of the points and in a similar fashion quickly realized that we need to find the average area of the sphere triangle formed by 3 random points on a sphere. After playing with it for about 10 minutes I didn't find anything useful and got slightly annoyed that this problem doesn't succumb to my power (I was quite overconfident back then as you can see!).


Anyway, as a diligent student I decided to look at lower dimensions. Similarly to the video, I computed the probability in the 2D case by doing an easy integral, and then, for a good measure, did a 1D case which is really just 4 cases since 1D-circle is discrete (I think this might have been a good thing to mention in the video, as to show that considering the simplest case is also fruitful even if it seems somewhat artificial). So, I got 1/4 and 1/2, and my intuition told me that the answer should be 1/8 and there might be some induction involved, although so far I had no idea how to prove it.



Here, I came to the first main idea: if fixing one point isn't enough, let's try to fix two points! So, let's say we've fixed points P_1 and P_2. What can we say about the other two? If we denote by S the plane through P_1, P_2 and the origin O, then, with a bit of convex geometry/linear algebra it's quite easy to see that the tetrahedron contains O if and only if the triangle P_1 P_2 P contains O, where P is the intersection of P_3P_4 and S. That is, P lies in the "opposite" triangle to the triangle P_1 P_2 O (it might be useful to draw some pictures here, but alas I can't do this in the comments for obvious reasons).



But how to compute the probability that S is in this triangle? Here is the second idea: I claim that this probability is proportional to the angle P_1OP_2!
Indeed, by rotational symmetry it's obvious that it only depends on this angle and if you put two such angles side by side then the probabilities, as well as angles, will add up, so by cutting the angle into n equal pieces and passing to the limit it's not hard to convince oneself in this proportionality.


But what is the proportionality constant? To find this let's pass to the extreme case, when the "triangle" P_1OP_2 is the whole plane S. Then the intersection lies in it if and only if P_3 and P_4 are on the different sides of S, so it is 1/2 (since hemispheres both have measure 1/2).


So, it remains to integrate the average value of the angle P_1OP_2. But didn't we discuss just a few paragraphs above that this is just an answer to the 2D case?! So, we just have to multiply the 2D answer by 1/2 and get 1/8! And the same surely works for all dimensions by induction.



I was so blinded and amazed by these ideas that I thought "this must be it" without being too critical of my own work. Do you see the mistake in the above argument?











The mistake is that I was too shameless in my use of independence. After we condition on the points P_1 and P_2 lying on some plane S, they are no longer independent and so the reduction to the 2D case doesn't work! The easiest way to see this is that if they were independent the probability that they were at most epsilon away from each other would be of order epsilon, but in reality it is of order epsilon^2 (the area of a small spherical cap with radius epsilon).

So, if they are not independent, then how are they distributed? To find it, we need help from our good old friend Archimedes, who more than two thousand years ago discovered that the area of a spherical cap is proportional to the height of this cap! (see 3b1b video "But why is a sphere's surface area four times its shadow?" to learn more about this piece of mathematics). And this height, up to some factors, is nothing but a cosine of a half of our desired angle P_1OP_2. So, the problem is basically reduced to integrating arccos(x) from -1 to 1.


At this point if I was on the real exam I would probably notice the symmetry x->-x, but this feels like the same kind of symmetry as in the video, and I wanted to avoid it, although one can say that I already used it back when I was computing the proportionality constant (by the way, here this symmetry can be visualized quite nicely by patching two complementing spherical caps to get the whole sphere). Thankfully, the antiderivative of arccos can be computed explicitly, if a bit painfully, and we can finish off the problem and get the correct answer 1/8 without the ingenious trick of considering point and its opposite altogether.



This turned out to be not quite as elegant as I have hoped for, and it really only works in dimension 3, but I still hope you can learn something from it.

Sorry, but the 'projection to the surface of a cylinder' approach does not suffice as a way of calculating the actual surface are of the sphere. It is a 'pretty' approach, but it fails (IMHO) because it does not prove why the projected elements reflect the actual area of the element in its position on the surface of the sphere.
So, since uniform-sized rectangles can never truly paint the surface of a sphere (there must be gaps between the square tiles) would not a more correct solution entail marking the sphere's surface with a geodesic layout. That will contain the usual set of five and six-sided figures, each containing its five or six triangles whose sizes are unique to either the five or six sided element and (importantly) no gaps between elements. Count these triangles and you get the surface area. Trend down the size of the elements towards zero, and you get a better approximation of the overall area.

Honestly? The surface of a sphere, cut correctly, has 4 circles in it.
For a sphere of radius r...
Use cubes of height h. Position cubes such that...
1) all cubes are in a regular grid (a-la Minecraft)
2) all points in the grid that intersect the sphere contain a cube.
Viewed from above, the cubes form into layers, and the cubes that are all visible can be ‘collected’ to create a circle of diameter r. There’s your first circle.
Viewed from below, you see the same sorts of layers forming, and you can repeat the collection process, yielding a second circle of diameter r.
You’ve now collected from the sphere all the cubes that were in horizontal layers, but that didn’t collect cubes from the middle of vertical layers, just the cubes at the edges of the vertical layers.
From the left side of the cube, collect layers for your third circle of diameter r, and repeat from the right side for the fourth and final circle of diameter r.
You’ve also collected every cube - there’s no more cubes left and thus no unaccounted for surface area.
The catch here is that cubes that would appear on corners belong both on a horizontal and a vertical layer, both, so the approximation has some error to it. You correct for that error by adjusting h down to zero, where the amount of error also becomes zero.

To me, a more intuitive mapping of spherical surface area to the area of the circle is to consider a dome, or half-sphere, split into rings, as in the video, illuminated from above, and to note that each ring shades the ground or equator circle to some percentage of itself. The ring at the top of the dome shades the circle to 100% of it's surface. The ring at the ground/equator shades the circle 0% of it's surface, since it is edge-on to the light. Splitting the difference, since the circle/sphere is completely symmetric, by definition, we get that the circle only 'uses' 50% of the shade, relative to the surface area. Thus the surface of a dome is 2x the area of the cross-section circle, and therefore the sphere is 4x.

Intuitiveness isn't about creating a (what I consider to be) convoluted way of finding your answer, and the only thing that connects your starting point and end result is a similar looking shape, but is about using simple enough terms, and concepts, to deduce the answer fast enough that your brain does not have to remind itself of some parameter that is precise, that you may have forgotten, or forgotten the significance of, by the time you reach the next step, or one of the next steps in the method.

it is very easily done with with just remedial trig ability and some visualization ability.
--Imagine our sphere as like the earth with latitude lines, the equator being 0 degrees.
--imagine that with a slice thru the equator. What is the area of the flat part(which is, in fact, the "shadow")
--The radius of the sphere is defined as 1. So the area of the shadow is 1^2 x pi = pi
--Divide that hemisphere into a very large number of equal thickness slices parallel to the equator say 1000.
--What is the area of each band? Length x width. The length is obviously proportional to the cosine of the latitude of the slice. The width is proportional to 1/cos of the same latitude. (You should easily be able to visualize why w/o my help, if not i could explain). cos x 1/cos = 1. We have demod that the sphere surface area on each slice, is the same for each slice.
--look at the large slice right at the equator, remember it is 0.001 thick, as are all the slices. The latitude is for all practical purposes 0, so the cosine is 1, so the width of that first band is simply 0.001. The length of that band is 2pi. So the area of the band is 0.001 x 2pi = 0.002pi
--There are 1000 bands, all of the same surface area, so the surface area of a hemisphere is 1000 x 0.002pi = 2pi
-- We already showed that the shadow's area is pi. We have showed that the hemispheres surface are is 2pi. So the hemispheres surface area is exactly twice the shadow
--So the surface area of the whole sphere is exactly 4 times the shadow.

The real question we should be asking with the presentation is - does it scale up and down. The measure of an (n-1)-sphere of radius r in n-dimensions is (√πr)ⁿ/(n/2)! using the convention that (-½)! = √π (so +(1/2)! = ½√π, +(3/2)! = ¾√π, etc.). You can verify this for the 2-sphere in 3-dimensions and the 1-sphere (or circle) in 2-dimensions. The perimeter for the (n-1)-sphere is 2πr(√πr)ⁿ⁻²/((n-2)/2)!, so the ratio of perimeter for (n-1) sphere to the measure of (n-2) sphere is 2√π ((n-1)/2)! / ((n-2)/2)! ... which for n = 3 is 2√π 1!/(½)! = 2√π/(½√π) = 4.

So, whatever explanation the video is presenting should explain all those other cases too! Or else it doesn't scale up and down. The "scale down" part is the case n = 2, where it comes out to π (which, of course, is: the circumference to diameter ratio). It's gotta explain that too. Or else, something specific to 3 dimensions has crept into the explanation. So, your next exercise is to generalize this to n dimensions for n ≥ 2 .. including n = 2 and even n = 1. For n = 1, 3, 5, 7, ..., the progression of ratios is 2, 2·2/1, 2·2/1·4/3, 2·2/1·4/3·6/5, ⋯, the general case being 2·(n-1)!!/(n-2)!! for odd n > 0; where double-factorials are defined by (-1)!! = 1 = 0!! and (k+2)!! = (k+2)·k!! for k = -1, 0, 1, 2, ⋯ For even n = 2, 4, 6, ... the ratio is π·(n-1)!!/(n-2)!!.

I have an intuitive geometric interpretation for the second part. I'm not sure if it qualifies as a proof or not:

Using x, y, z axes in the right, up, and inside directions respectively.

Consider a top hemisphere on the xz-plane, and its y projection to a circle (call it PC). Now using the rectangles (call it OR) from the first part, we ignore the width of the OR and just consider its height, H, defined as the tangent of a circle along the xz-plane. Let the length of the projected rectangle (call it PR) be P. It follows that P = 0 at the equator, and P = H at the pole. Now consider a length on OR called E (for extra), such that E + P = H. It follows that E = H at the equator, and E = 0 at the pole. So we have 0 <= P, E <= H. Hence we can create a area from the area lost during projection equal to PC. As a hemisphere curved area is 2 projected circles area, a sphere curved area is 4 projected circles area.

• Circumference = 2pi × r
• Area of a Triangle = (h × w) ÷ 2

I like the video. Being picky though, there are some significant gaps in the proofs which are very technical to fully rigorously cover.
In each proof, we end up approximating areas using certain, simpler geometric shapes, such as approximating the rings with annuli (the actual rings are on a curved surface). Of course, these approximations get very close in area as the d-thetas get small, but then you're also summing up more and more of them. How do we know that summing up lots of these little errors doesn't cause a mistake?
As an analogy, put a circle with radius 1 in a square grid of paper (grid as fine as you want). Approximate the circle by the zig-zag of lines following the grid, just outside of the circle. Even if your grid is very fine, the length that you'll work out for your approximation of the circumference is always at least 8 (and exactly 8 if the fineness perfectly divides the diameter, such as if you take squares in your grid of length 1/2^n). So your "approximation" never approaches the correct 2pi.
This doesn't happen here. It's intuitive "why", since the normals of our "approximating surfaces" are in some sense getting closer to the actual normal to the surface so are "better" to some higher degree. But that still seems to need proof. I don't think there is a very slick way to adjust the proofs to make them totally watertight. You'd need to keep track of the errors for each d-theta. Could be done, for sure, but I think that the nice, visual, simple and intuitive aspects of these proofs is somewhat an illusion, based on the fact that they don't actually give the full details necessary.
That said, I totally agree that a flipped style of teaching - doing this kind of stuff to build intuition for calculus/geometry - is a really good idea.

There is also a very nice method of determining the surface area formula of the sphere from the formula for its volume: the volume is V(r) = 4/3r³π. If we change the radius r of some fixed sphere by some infinitesimal amount ε, the change in volume is V(r + ε) = V(r) + A(r)ε + o(ε) where A(r) is the surface area. So in other words, A(r) is the derivative of V(r). And indeed, d/dr (4/3r³π) = 4r²π.

It was a very nice video. But I want to point out an inaccuracy at 9:35. Although, this was perhaps meant to be hidden under the rug for simplicity's sake. This is totally fine but I provide an explanation below.

The approximation of the sphere does not consist exactly of rectangles but of trapezoids. So what is meant by the statement "the sphere rectangles have the same area as the cylinder rectangles" and depicted in the diagram is not exactly true. What is true is: if the area of the "sphere rectangles" is off from the area of the sphere by E_S > 0, the area of the "cylinder rectangles" is off from the "sphere rectangles" by E_CS > 0, and the area of the "cylinder rectangles" is off from the area of the cylinder by E_C > 0, then as the "coverings" get finer, each error goes to 0 so E_S + E_CS + E_C goes to 0.

The fact that E_S and E_C goes to 0 is of course believable (this is how area of surfaces are defined). However arguing E_CS goes to 0 is slightly less trivial. Here is the idea without going into the math. The error between the trapezoids and its corresponding rectangle is small in the "band" around the equator. This band of well behaved trapezoids get thicker as the "covering" gets finer. This error is much worse near the poles but the error is trivially at most the area of the two "caps" which fit on the top and bottom of the "band". But as the covering gets finer the band gets thicker, so the area of the caps go to 0.

Congrats on such an amazing video, omg it's 3AM but here's how I did the exercise proof:

1. The circumference length of each ring is 2*pi*R*sin(theta), since the distance from the ring to the axis is R* sin(theta) (trigonometry). Hence, the area of a ring is 2*pi*R*sin(theta)*R*d_theta = 2*pi*R^2*sin(theta)*d_theta (1)

2. To calculate the area of a ring's shadow, I used some trig relations as well. In this case, the thickness of the ring shadow is R*d_theta*cos(theta). Therefore, the area of the ring shadow is 2*pi*R^2*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d_theta (2)

3. Multiplying by both sides expression (2), we get 2*pi*R^2*2*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d_theta
I've put the number 2 right next to sin(theta)*cos(theta) to explicit the trigonometrical relation:

2*sin(theta)*cos(theta) = sin(2*theta)

That specific angle is 2*theta.

4. So, this means that the area of the shadow of some ring with a corresponding angle of theta is equal to the area of a ring which has double of this angle.

5. Notice that, when theta ranges from zero to pi/2, we get to form all of the rings related to their shadows in the superior hemisphere. The total area of the shadow is the sum of all the thin ring shadows. Thus, that is equal to half the area of the hemisphere. That is, the area of the shadow (pi*R^2) is 1/4 of the surface area of the sphere. A(sphere) = 4*pi*R^2 Q.E.D.

think of that triangle similarity, you get difference = R*d(theta)*cos(theta) larger area circle=(pi)*(R*sin(theta)+cos(theta)*R*d(theta))(squared) Shadow ring = (pi)*(R*sin(theta)+cos(theta)*R*d(theta))(squared) - (pi)*(R*sin(theta))(squared)
Q3 = Shadow area of ring = 1/2 (some other ring) set the unknown ring has radius X (pi)*(R*sin(theta)+cos(theta)*R*d(theta))(squared) - (pi)*(R*sin(theta))(squared) = 1/2*(2*(pi)*R(squared)*d(theta)*X and then (pi)*(R*sin(theta)+cos(theta)*R*d(theta))(squared) - (pi)*(R*sin(theta))(squared) = (pi)*R(squared)*(sin(theta))(squared)+2*pi*R(squared)*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d(theta) + (pi)*cos(theta)(squared)*R(squared)*d(theta)(squared) - (pi)*(R*sin(theta))(squared). The term [(pi)*R(squared)*(sin(theta))(squared)] and the term [ - (pi)*(R*sin(theta))(squared)] cancels out each other perfectly, while the term (pi)*cos(theta)(squared)*R(squared)*... ...*d(theta)(squared) can be ignored since d*(theta)(squared) will be very tiny as d(theta) approaches zero, and the expression is left as 2*(pi)*R(squared)*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d(theta) = 1/2*(2*(pi)*R(squared)*d(theta)*X 1/2 times 2 cancels out 2*(pi)*R(squared)*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d(theta) = (pi)*R(squared)*d(theta)*X 2*sin(theta)*cos(theta)*d(theta) = d(theta)*X 2*sin(theta)*cos(theta) = X Since 2*sin(theta)*cos(theta)=sin(2*(theta)) sin(2*(theta)) = X Angle = 2*(theta) Since new ring angle is TWICE the original ring angle, therefore the shadow ring area is 1/2 of every other ring on the sphere IN ANY RATIO.
Q4 Combine the shadow rings into a circle. And all luckily chosen rings on the sphere fits PERFECTLY into a half sphere.
Q5 From Q4, we can see that the area of a sphere's shadow is 1/2 the surface area of 1/2 of a sphere. +3Blue1:   There is a much simpler, more clear way to visualize that the cylinder is the same area as the sphere.   (Fact is, some of the material at 3:20 is truly confusing).

Entirely forget about the little squares, and focus instead upon dividing the cylinder into many equal size bands, and its corresponding equal thickness bands upon the sphere. (As if you put the sphere in the cylinder and sliced thru both, directly crosswise with a knife).  Say, maybe the cylinder is 1 meter, sliced into 1000 1mm slices, and the corresponding 1000 slices of the sphere.

Notice that at the equator the surface area of a slice of the cyl is exactly the same as the surface area of the slice of the sphere, obviously.  So to prove the whole cyl area is the same as the  sphere are, all we need to do is demo that any sphere band has the same area as any of those 1mm cyl bands

(Let L = the length of the cyl band). ( Let W = the width of the cyl band).   Obviously, at any chosen latitude, the length of the sphere band is  L x (cos of latitude).  The width of the sphere band is W / (cos of latitude).   L x W = area.   Obviously the 1/cos and cos cancel each other out in the area calc, leaving  any sphere band exactly the same area as any cyl band.

In practice for the given case:   A cyl  band area is simply 1mm x 1000mm x pi = 3141.6 mm^2.   So, say for example at 60 deg latitude, the sphere band width is 1mm / cos60deg, and the sphere band length is 1000mm x pi  x cos60 deg.    The cos of 60 deg = 0.5.   (1mm / 0.5) x (1000mm x 3.1416 x 0.5)   =  31416.6 mm^2, which, notice,  is exactly the same are as any cyl band  

So every cyl band is exactly the same size as its corresponding sphere band, so obviously the cyl must be the same surface area as the sphere.

Really good, and it took me a while to find the complete solution. The answers to Q1-Q3 are easy, but the factor 4 is still hard to find.
A1-A3: The projected area of a ring at angle θ has a size dA'=2𝜋 R^2 cosθsinθdθ. The given sine rule tells that this is equal to 𝜋 R^2sin(2θ)dθ.

Spoiler: The point is that this is also equal to  ½ (2𝜋R^2sin(2θ)dθ). 
This implies that every ring at angle θ in the upper hemisphere gives a projection that has an area of half the size of the area of a ring on the sphere at angle 2θ. When we sum up all the projections coming from rings of the upper hemisphere, we get an area of 𝜋R^2. 
But this turns out to be equivalent to a quarter of the total sphere surface. 
We have the factor 2 from the sinus rule, as explained above, but also a factor 2 due to the jumps between consecutive summations of the equivalent 2θ rings.
 
The factor from the jumps becomes clear when we just do the following. First we take a ring in the upper hemisphere between angle θ and θ+dθ. This gives a projected ring which has half the area of the ring between 2θ and 2θ+dθ. The consecutive ring in the upper hemisphere lies between θ+dθ and θ+2dθ. The projection has half the area of the ring between 2θ+2dθ and 2θ+3dθ. We observe that we have skipped the ring between 2θ+dθ to 2θ+2dθ. This happens for every following step. In a way we are jumping to conclusions :-). When we finished all the rings of the upper hemisphere from θ=0 to θ=𝜋/2, we have integrated not half the value of the rings areas (from θ=0 to θ=𝜋), but also one half of the rings between θ=0 to θ=𝜋). Therefore one fourth of the total surface area of a sphere.

I started with different notation on challenge part, and stayed with it later.
The moment I've seen the animation with rings I thought about splicing into 2N parts, so that from the side it looks like 4N-pieces pizza. Four -- because of symmetry. So each splice has angular size of α = π / 2N.
This way we can enumerate all rings from top to bottom from 0 to 2N-1 (or just N-1 for one hemisphere).
Inner radius of k-th ring is L_k = 2πR * sin(kα), their thickness is all the same and is equal to l = πR / 2N.
Area S_k = l * L_k.

Now comes the strange part.
Answering Question#3 we get answer like this: projected ring has area Sp_k = S_2k / 2.
Aaaaand this is weird. If we assume k = 0 -- it's that small hat on top of the sphere. Its projection has area Sp_0 = S_0 / 2.
But we're doing projection parallel to z-axis, so logically we can assume, that it should have (almost) the same area as its projection, not the half of it. At this point my inner Archimedes starts to make tin foil hat for himself...

Apart from this, noticing how some rings are equal to each other (S_k = S_(2N-k-1)), further solution is easy.

Couldn't find out where "every other" concentric strip came up, but here's my attempt.

Showing that surfaceArea(sphere) = 4(pi)r^2 is equivalent to showing surfaceArea(semisphere) = 2(pi)r^2. Since each semicircle projects down into a circle of area (pi)r^2, this implies the area of the projected circle is exactly half the surface area of the semicircle that projects it.

Define (d) as the distance from the vertical plane to the bottom of each semicircle strip. For strips of small width, each strip has area 2(pi)(d)(width), while their projections have the limit area 2(pi)(d)(projected width). The ratio of the two areas is then exactly the proportion of the two widths. Taking the height (h) as the distance from the x-y plane to the bottom of the strip, we can show (https://imgur.com/a/BRRQc72 ) that the ratio (projected width)/(width) equals (h)/(R).

As we take more strips, splitting the sphere more and more finely, the values of (h)/(R) going up the circle from the middle plane increase evenly. Specifically, they start to approximate a linear function of (h) from 0 to R [alternatively, (h)/(r) from 0 to 1]. And vitally, with enough strips, any strip at (h)/(R) will have a "partner" strip very close to 1 - (h)/(R) such that their average 1/2((h)/(R) + 1 - (h)/(R)) approaches 1/2.

Thus in the limit of fine strips (more and more strips have a partner,) the average value of (h)/(R) = (projected width)/(width) = (projected circle area)/(surface area) approaches 1/2, and the projected area (pi)r^2 is half the surface area of the semicircle.

Next for each of the blank segments top and bottom, mark the point on the center circle (the one touching the sphere) directly above or below the middle of the segment. After this you can cut out equilateral triangles from the ends of each of the blank segments towards these points halfway along the cilinder. In our case 20 triangles. These triangles you can flip upwards and attach to the marked portions of the original circles. You end up with a kind of spiky bracelet, but if you then fold the points of those spikes together until the edges are flush, you should approximate the sphere you started with. Of course this way wil impart fewer calculus principles than your demonstration, only really that as your building blocks approach zero area, their shape in relation to the shape you're building becomes less relevant. But on the plus side you could do it in a classroom.

Here's a sketch of the proof for general convex shapes:
Tile the surface really finely and look at a single piece of surface area. Consider how the piece moves as you twist the whole shape. As the shape assumes all possible orientations, so does the piece, no matter where the center of rotation. The sum of the piece rotated in all directions around a fixed point is a sphere. The sum of its shadows is the sphere's shadow. The lower half of the sphere represents all those orientations in which the surface piece is on the bottom of the shape and doesn't cast a shadow. (This doesn't work for concave shapes where shadows may overlap.) This means the average ratio of surface to shadow area of a small piece is the same as a sphere's. If this is true for each piece of surface, so must it be for their sum.
Averaged over all possible rotations, the ratio of surface to shadow area of any convex shape is 4.

Answers below the fold:

Q1: Let's call the radius of the ring d. We have a right triangle with an angle of theta and a hypotenuse of R. In this case, d is opposite from theta. Using the above mnemonic, we can remember that O/H = sin(theta), ergo d = R sin(theta). The circumference of a circle is 2 pi R, so the inner circumference of the ring is 2 pi R sin(theta).
Thus the ring's area is approximately 2 pi R^2 sin(theta) d(theta).

Q2: The good news is that our inner radius d is the same as it was for the ring on the sphere, ergo the inner circumference will also be the same: 2 pi R sin(theta). What we need to figure out is the thickness of the ring's shadow. By drawing another right triangle where the hypotenuse is the thickness of the ring, R d(theta), we can see that the thickness of the shadow is adjacent to theta in our new triangle. Using the mnemonic above, we can see that A/H = cos(theta), ergo the thickness of the shadow = R cos(theta) d(theta). To finish off, we multiply these two to get an area of 2 pi R^2 sin(theta) cos(theta) d(theta).

Q3: Using the identity that 2 sin(theta) cos(theta) = sin(2*theta) reveals that we can rewrite the area of the shadow as pi R^2 sin(2*theta) d(theta). This is the same as the area of the ring except that we've dropped the 2 from in front, signifying that we've cut the value in half, but we've also doubled the value of theta. This means that the shadow at a given value of theta has half the area of the ring at double that theta value. For example, the shadow at theta = 30 degrees has half the area of the ring at 60 degrees. Thus, as we go to the next shadow, we skip past one of the rings and jump two rings ahead instead of one.

Q4: Partially answered above, but as we compare each shadow to a ring on the sphere, we have to skip every other ring, jumping two rings ahead for each shadow. The other half of this puzzle is to remember that we only generated shadows from one hemisphere rather than the entire sphere. Since we skip one ring for each shadow, that means we need to use all of the rings from the entire sphere (except for the ones we jump over), instead of just using the rings from one hemisphere. An easy way to see this is to think about the last shadow, at theta = 90 degrees, which corresponds to half the area of the ring at 180 degrees, which is the last ring on the sphere.

Q5: The area of the shadows sums up to the area of a circle of radius R. However, each shadow is only half the area of one of the rings, and only half of the rings have been accounted for. A half of a half is one quarter. Ergo, a circle of radius R only has half the area of one hemisphere of the sphere, which in turn only has half the area of the whole sphere, and thus the area of the circle is one quarter that of the entire sphere.

2. Using the trig identity given in the video (sin(2*theta)=2*sin(theta)*cos(theta)), it is clear that the area of this new ring is sin(2*theta)/cos(theta) times the area of the given ring.

Speaking of geometry as an intro to calculus, there’s an interesting derivation of the derivative of the unit circle. All you need to know is that the tangent line is perpendicular to the radius, and that perpendicular lines have slopes that are negative reciprocals. Simply start with the unit circle, x^2+y^2=1. To find the derivative at (x,y), we can draw the tangent line to the graph. We can also add in the radius. We know the center of the circle is (0,0), so using the standard slope formula you get m=y/x. To find the derivative, we know it is -1/m=-x/y from being perpendicular. And that’s how you find the derivative of a circle without any implicit differentiation
